1. An 8-year-old girl presents to the pediatric neurology clinic with a three-month history of persistent headaches and progressively worsening difficulty with eye movements. Her parents also report unsteady gait and frequent falls over the last few weeks. On examination, she has horizontal nystagmus, mild facial weakness, and decreased sensation in her left arm. There is evidence of axial ataxia and dysarthria. MRI of the brain reveals a well-circumscribed, T2 hyperintense lesion centered in the pons, consistent with a brainstem astrocytoma. No signs of hydrocephalus are visible at this stage. The child has no significant past medical history and meets developmental milestones appropriately. The clinical picture and imaging findings raise concern for a low-grade brainstem glioma, which requires further neuro-oncological evaluation.
